Graphical abstract

Four cadmium coordination polymers containing aliphatic dicarboxylate and dipyridylamide ligands were structurally characterized. {[Cd(dms)(4-pmina)]⋅2.5H2O} n  (3, dms=2,2-dimethylsuccinate, 4-pmina=4-pyridylmethylisonicotinamide) shows a 2-fold interpenetrated net with (426)(426583) topology (pictured). Higher temperature afforded {[Cd4(dms)4(H2O)4]⋅H2O} n  (4), which shows a dia 66 net featuring cuboid {Cd4O4} clusters. The 3-D phase 3 showed potential as a detector for nitrobenzene.

elements.clean_text:
Cadmium coordination polymers with substituted aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands.

Isomeric flexible dipyridylamide coligands.

1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymer dimensionality depending on ligands.

Rare 2-fold interpenetrated (426)(426583) topology for dimethylsuccinate derivative.

Luminescent behavior and nitrobenzene detection capability.

Abstract

Hydrothermal reaction of cadmium nitrate, a dimethyl-substituted aliphatic α,ω-carboxylic acid, and a flexible dipyridylamide ligand afforded four crystalline coordination polymers whose dimensionality and topology depended on the nitrogen donor disposition within the dipyridyl subunit and the length of the aliphatic chain subunit. These new crystalline phases were structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. {[Cd(dmg)(3-pmna)(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1, dmg=2,2-dimethylglutarate, 3-pmna=3-pyridylmethylnicotinamide) manifests a simple (4,4) grid structure. {[Cd(dms)(3-pmna)(H2O)]⋅4.5H2O} n  (2, dms=2,2-dimethylsuccinate) displays a 1D coordination polymer ladder motif with looped pairs of struts. {[Cd(dms)(4-pmina)]⋅2.5H2O} n  (3, 4-pmina=4-pyridylmethylisonicotinamide) shows a 3,5-connected 2-fold interpenetrated binodal net with (426)(426583) topology, wherein the 4-pmina ligands serve as 3-connected nodes. Higher temperature synthetic regimes afforded {[Cd4(dms)4(H2O)4]⋅H2O} n  (4) which manifests a 66 diamondoid topology based on [Cd4(dms)4(H2O)4] n  subunits with embedded cuboid {Cd4O4} tetranuclear clusters. Thermal and luminescent properties of these new materials are also presented. The 3-D phase 3 showed potential as a detector for nitrobenzene.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">For the past two decades, there has been a significant basic research focus on the synthesis and structure of divalent metal coordination polymer solids containing dicarboxylate and dipyridyl ligands. These solid state materials show potential as substrates for gas storage , shape-selective molecular separations , ion exchange , heterogeneous catalysis , and more recently as detectors for nitroaromatic residues of explosive compounds . Additionally, the aesthetic attractiveness of these materials’ underlying geometric topologies continues to spur exploratory synthesis . Coordination polymers based on divalent cadmium can exhibit useful optical properties, imparted by the closed shell <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> electronic configuration of this metal ion. The full <ce:italic>d</ce:italic> shell electron population results in forbidden visible light <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>d</ce:italic> transitions, providing the necessary transparent visible light spectral window required for nitroaromatics sensing  or non-linear optical applications .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

For the past two decades, there has been a significant basic research focus on the synthesis and structure of divalent metal coordination polymer solids containing dicarboxylate and dipyridyl ligands. These solid state materials show potential as substrates for gas storage , shape-selective molecular separations , ion exchange , heterogeneous catalysis , and more recently as detectors for nitroaromatic residues of explosive compounds . Additionally, the aesthetic attractiveness of these materials' underlying geometric topologies continues to spur exploratory synthesis . Coordination polymers based on divalent cadmium can exhibit useful optical properties, imparted by the closed shell d 10 electronic configuration of this metal ion. The full d shell electron population results in forbidden visible light d-d transitions, providing the necessary transparent visible light spectral window required for nitroaromatics sensing  or non-linear optical applications .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Structural diversity among dicarboxylate/dipyridyl cadmium-based coordination polymers is wide in scope because of the absence of crystal field stabilization and resultant coordination geometry flexibility . Coordination polymer structure direction during self-assembly is thereby finely tuned by the synergistic effects of dipyridyl ligand donor disposition and carboxylate binding mode. Alteration of chain length and substituent-based steric bulk of aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands can also enhance the topological scope of these cadmium-containing coordination polymers . The conformational fluxionality of the aliphatic chains of these ligands instills an active response to specific supramolecular environments, while bulky substituents can restrict access to some conformations or potential binding modes during coordination polymer self-assembly.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Structural diversity among dicarboxylate/dipyridyl cadmium-based coordination polymers is wide in scope because of the absence of crystal field stabilization and resultant coordination geometry flexibility . Coordination polymer structure direction during self-assembly is thereby finely tuned by the synergistic effects of dipyridyl ligand donor disposition and carboxylate binding mode. Alteration of chain length and substituent-based steric bulk of aliphatic dicarboxylate ligands can also enhance the topological scope of these cadmium-containing coordination polymers . The conformational fluxionality of the aliphatic chains of these ligands instills an active response to specific supramolecular environments, while bulky substituents can restrict access to some conformations or potential binding modes during coordination polymer self-assembly.

elements.clean_text: Both {[Cd(suc)(bpy)]⋅0.25H2O} n  (suc=succinate, bpy=4,4'-bipyridine) and {[Cd(suc)(dpa)]⋅H2O} n  (dpa=4,4'-dipyridylamine) display dimer-based 2-fold interpenetrated 41263 primitive cubic-type nets , as does [Cd(glu)(dpa)] n  . The related dipyridylamide ligand 4-pyridylisonicotinamide (4-pina) also afforded a 3D dimer-based net in [Cd(suc)(4-pina)] n , but this complex exhibits a rarer 446108 mab self-penetrated topology . The acentric coordination polymer {[Cd(dms)(bpy)(H2O)2]⋅H2O} n  (dms=2,2-dimethylsuccinate,  ) exhibits four-fold 1D homochiral right-handed helical [Cd(dms)] n  chain motifs conjoined through bpy tethers to construct a 658 cds 3D network . [Cd(dms)(dpa)] n  manifests acentric doubly interpenetrated (4,4) rhomboid grid layers . These results indicate that greater steric bulk within the dicarboxylate component can alter 3D topology and can even afford a reduction in coordination polymer dimensionality.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The isomeric dipyridylamide 4-pyridylmethylisonicotinamide (4-pmina, ), with a more linear donor disposition, has not seen much employment in the construction of coordination polymers to date. Either the 3-pmna or 4-pmina ligand can engage in both supramolecular hydrogen bonding donating and accepting mechanisms due to their central amide moieties, unlike the kinked dpa or rigid-rod bpy linkers, affording a plethora of structure-directing capabilities.</ce:para>

Either the 3-pmna or 4-pmina ligand can engage in both supramolecular hydrogen bonding donating and accepting mechanisms due to their central amide moieties, unlike the kinked dpa or rigid-rod bpy linkers, affording a plethora of structure-directing capabilities.

<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). These phases show a very significant change in coordination polymer dimensionality and topology depending on the nitrogen donor disposition if the dipyridylamide ligand is present, and also the length of the dimethyl-substituted aliphatic dicarboxylate chain. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> also showed promise as a detector for nitrobenzene in solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this contribution we report the synthesis, single-crystal structural characterization, luminescent properties, and thermal degradation behavior of four new coordination polymers prepared in the presence of substituted aliphatic dicarboxylate and dipyridylamide ligands: {[Cd(dmg)(3-pmna)(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1, dmg=2,2-dimethylglutarate), {[Cd(dms)(3-pmna)(H2O)]⋅4.5H2O} n  (2), {[Cd(dms)(4-pmina)]⋅2.5H2O} n  (3), and {[Cd4(dms)4(H2O)4]⋅H2O} n  (4). These phases show a very significant change in coordination polymer dimensionality and topology depending on the nitrogen donor disposition if the dipyridylamide ligand is present, and also the length of the dimethyl-substituted aliphatic dicarboxylate chain. Compound 3 also showed promise as a detector for nitrobenzene in solution.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">General considerations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Cadmium nitrate, dicarboxylic acids, and nitrobenzene were obtained commercially. The dipyridylamide ligands 3-pyridylmethylnicotinamide (3-pmna) and 4-pyridylmethylisonicotinamide (4-pmina) were synthesized by adaptation of the literature procedure for the preparation of 4-pyridylisonicotinamide, using 3-picolylamine and 4-picolylamine as the respective precursors, with nicotinoyl chloride hydrochloride employed for the synthesis of 3-pmna . Water was deionized above 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MΩ–cm in-house. Elemental analysis was carried out using a Perkin Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O Analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on powdered samples using a Perkin Elmer Spectrum One instrument. The luminescence spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were obtained with a Hitachi F-4500 Fluorescence Spectrometer on solid crystalline samples anchored to quartz microscope slides with Rexon Corporation RX-22P ultraviolet-transparent epoxy adhesive. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a TA Instruments Q50 thermal analyzer under flowing N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. Topological analysis of coordination polymer networks was carried out using <ce:small-caps>topos</ce:small-caps> software .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General considerations

Cadmium nitrate, dicarboxylic acids, and nitrobenzene were obtained commercially. The dipyridylamide ligands 3-pyridylmethylnicotinamide (3-pmna) and 4-pyridylmethylisonicotinamide (4-pmina) were synthesized by adaptation of the literature procedure for the preparation of 4-pyridylisonicotinamide, using 3-picolylamine and 4-picolylamine as the respective precursors, with nicotinoyl chloride hydrochloride employed for the synthesis of 3-pmna . Water was deionized above 3MΩ-cm in-house. Elemental analysis was carried out using a Perkin Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS/O Analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on powdered samples using a Perkin Elmer Spectrum One instrument. The luminescence spectra of 1-4 were obtained with a Hitachi F-4500 Fluorescence Spectrometer on solid crystalline samples anchored to quartz microscope slides with Rexon Corporation RX-22P ultraviolet-transparent epoxy adhesive. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a TA Instruments Q50 thermal analyzer under flowing N2. Topological analysis of coordination polymer networks was carried out using topos software .

Preparation of {[Cd(dmg)(3-pmna)(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1)

Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (115mg, 0.372mmol), 3-pmna (76mg, 0.36mmol), 2,2-dimethylglutaric acid (58mg, 0.37mmol), and 1mL of a 1.0M NaOH solution were mixed with 10mL of distilled H2O in a 23mL Teflon-lined acid digestion bomb. <ce:section-title id="st060">Nitroaromatics detection studies for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">A 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg sample of coordination polymer <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was suspended in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL ethanol in a volumetric flask, with immersion in an ultrasonic bath for 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min to ensure an even dispersion. The fluorescence spectrum was recorded with an excitation wavelength of 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. A stock solutions of nitrobenzene and benzene (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M) in dimethyl sulfoxide were prepared. Aliquots of these stock solution were added sequentially to the coordination polymer ethanol suspension with sonication for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s. The emission spectra were measured before any analyte addition and after each aliquot of analyte solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Nitroaromatics detection studies for 3 

A 5mg sample of coordination polymer 3 was suspended in 5mL ethanol in a volumetric flask, with immersion in an ultrasonic bath for 5min to ensure an even dispersion. The fluorescence spectrum was recorded with an excitation wavelength of 300nm. A stock solutions of nitrobenzene and benzene (1×10-4 M) in dimethyl sulfoxide were prepared. Aliquots of these stock solution were added sequentially to the coordination polymer ethanol suspension with sonication for 30s. The emission spectra were measured before any analyte addition and after each aliquot of analyte solution.

<ce:section-title id="st065">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">Diffraction data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were collected on a Bruker-AXS SMART-CCD X-ray diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The data were processed via <ce:small-caps>saint</ce:small-caps>
 and subjected to Lorentz effect, polarization effect and absorption corrections using <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps>
 (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) or <ce:small-caps>twinabs</ce:small-caps> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) . The crystal of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was nonmerohedrally twinned. The twin law was ascertained using <ce:small-caps>cellnow</ce:small-caps>
; only the data from the major twin component was used for the structure solution and refinement. The structures were solved using direct methods with <ce:small-caps>shelxtl</ce:small-caps>
 using the <ce:small-caps>olex</ce:small-caps>2 software suite . The dmg ligands in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were disordered over two sets of positions and modeled successfully using partial occupancies. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. Crystallographic details for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Diffraction data for 1-4 were collected on a Bruker-AXS SMART-CCD X-ray diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). The data were processed via saint  and subjected to Lorentz effect, polarization effect and absorption corrections using sadabs  (1, 2, 4) or twinabs (3) . The crystal of 3 was nonmerohedrally twinned. The twin law was ascertained using cellnow ; only the data from the major twin component was used for the structure solution and refinement. The structures were solved using direct methods with shelxtl  using the olex2 software suite . The dmg ligands in 1 were disordered over two sets of positions and modeled successfully using partial occupancies. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. Crystallographic details for 1-4 are given in  .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st070">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st075">Synthesis and Infrared Spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were prepared cleanly by hydrothermal reaction of cadmium nitrate, the requisite dimethyl-substituted dicarboxylic acid, and either 3-pmna (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) or 4-pmina (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). No 3-pmna was included within the crystal structure of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, although its presence is required to produce a clean sample of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. It is plausible that 3-pmna, or its hydrolysis products, are acting as mineralizers. Infrared spectra were consistent with the structural components as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Broad, weak bands at ∼3300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> signify the O–H bonds in the water molecules of crystallization and 3-pmna and 4-pmina N–H bonds. Weaker, high energy bands at ∼3000–3200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are attributed to C–H bond stretching modes in all cases. Asymmetric and symmetric C−O stretching modes of the dicarboxylate ligands are marked by strong bands at 1543<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 1414<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), 1560<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 1411<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), 1537<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 1398<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), and 1514<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 1395<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). Sharp, medium intensity bands in the range of ∼1600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> to ∼1200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> are attributed to the stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of the dipyridylamide ligands . Features corresponding to pyridyl and aryl ring puckering are observed in the region between 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Sharp, moderate intensity bands at 1655<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, 1647<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and 1648<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> denote the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O stretching modes dipyridylamide ligands for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively. There are no dipyridylamide ligands in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, so such an amide C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O band is absent.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and Infrared Spectroscopy

Compounds 1-4 were prepared cleanly by hydrothermal reaction of cadmium nitrate, the requisite dimethyl-substituted dicarboxylic acid, and either 3-pmna (1, 2, 4) or 4-pmina (3). No 3-pmna was included within the crystal structure of 4, although its presence is required to produce a clean sample of 4. It is plausible that 3-pmna, or its hydrolysis products, are acting as mineralizers. Infrared spectra were consistent with the structural components as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Broad, weak bands at ~3300cm-1 signify the O-H bonds in the water molecules of crystallization and 3-pmna and 4-pmina N-H bonds. Weaker, high energy bands at ~3000-3200cm-1 are attributed to C-H bond stretching modes in all cases. Asymmetric and symmetric C-O stretching modes of the dicarboxylate ligands are marked by strong bands at 1543cm-1 and 1414cm-1 (1), 1560cm-1 and 1411cm-1 (2), 1537cm-1 and 1398cm-1 (3), and 1514cm-1 and 1395cm-1 (4). Sharp, medium intensity bands in the range of ~1600cm-1 to ~1200cm-1 are attributed to the stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of the dipyridylamide ligands . Features corresponding to pyridyl and aryl ring puckering are observed in the region between 800cm-1 and 600cm-1. Sharp, moderate intensity bands at 1655cm-1, 1647cm-1, and 1648cm-1 denote the CO stretching modes dipyridylamide ligands for 1-3, respectively. There are no dipyridylamide ligands in 4, so such an amide CO band is absent.

Structural description of {[Cd(dmg)(3-pmna)(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1)

The asymmetric unit of compound 1 contains a divalent cadmium atom, a disordered dmg ligand, a 3-pmna ligand, an aqua ligand, and one water molecule of crystallization. The cadmium atoms display a {CdO5N2} pentagonal bipyramidal geometry ( ), with the apical positions being occupied by pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms from two 3-pmna ligands. Chelating carboxylate groups from two dmg ligands and the bound water molecule fill the equatorial plane. Bond lengths and angles within the pentagonal bipyramidal environment are listed in  .

Structural description of {[Cd(dms)(3-pmna)(H2O)]⋅4.5H2O} n  (2)

The asymmetric unit of compound 2 consists of a divalent cadmium atom, a dms ligand, a 3-pmna ligand, a bound water molecule, and net four and one half water molecules of crystallization. Similar to 1, the coordination environment is a {CdO5N2} pentagonal bipyramid ( ), albeit with cis disposed 3-pmna pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms in axial and equatorial positions. The other axial site is occupied by an aqua ligand. Chelating carboxylate groups from two dms ligands fill the remaining four equatorial coordination sites. Bond lengths and angles within the pentagonal bipyramidal coordination sphere are listed in  .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0135" view="all">Bis(chelating) dms ligands with an anti conformation (four-C atom torsion angle<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>171.7°) conjoin cadmium atoms into [Cd(dms)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> coordination polymer chains oriented parallel to the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> crystal direction (a); the Cd⋯Cd through-ligand distance measures 9.156<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. These chain subunits are linked into [Cd(dms)(4-pmina)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (4,4) coordination polymer grid motifs by the full span of the 4-pmina ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>b); these are arranged parallel to the <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> crystal planes. Unlike <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, in which the dipyridylamide ligands serve only as dipodal linkers, the 4-pmina carbonyl oxygen atoms serve as donors to cadmium. As a result, the (4,4) coordination polymer layer subunits are further connected into a two-fold interpenetrated 3,5-connected binodal 3D net (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>) in which the cadmium atoms act as 5-connected nodes and the 4-pmina ligands act as 3-connected nodes. According to a topological analysis performed with <ce:small-caps>topos</ce:small-caps>, the interpenetrated nets possess a new (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6)(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) topology (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>). Water molecules of crystallization are located in channels within the system of interpenetrated nets situated along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> crystal direction, anchored to the coordination polymer frameworks by accepting hydrogen bonds from 4-pmina N–H bonds and by donating hydrogen bonds to ligated dms carboxylate oxygen atoms (). The unligated water molecules form hydrogen-bonded tapes with alternating cyclic tetramer and hexamer units (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>), with a T4(0)6(0) classification denoting no sharing of molecules between the ring motifs . According to <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps>, the water-bearing cavities comprise 11.6% of the unit cell volume.</ce:para>

These chain subunits are linked into [Cd(dms)(4-pmina)] n  (4,4) coordination polymer grid motifs by the full span of the 4-pmina ligands ( b); these are arranged parallel to the bc crystal planes. Unlike 1 and 2, in which the dipyridylamide ligands serve only as dipodal linkers, the 4-pmina carbonyl oxygen atoms serve as donors to cadmium. As a result, the (4,4) coordination polymer layer subunits are further connected into a two-fold interpenetrated 3,5-connected binodal 3D net ( ) in which the cadmium atoms act as 5-connected nodes and the 4-pmina ligands act as 3-connected nodes. According to a topological analysis performed with topos, the interpenetrated nets possess a new (426)(426583) topology ( ). Water molecules of crystallization are located in channels within the system of interpenetrated nets situated along the a crystal direction, anchored to the coordination polymer frameworks by accepting hydrogen bonds from 4-pmina N-H bonds and by donating hydrogen bonds to ligated dms carboxylate oxygen atoms (). The unligated water molecules form hydrogen-bonded tapes with alternating cyclic tetramer and hexamer units ( ), with a T4(0)6(0) classification denoting no sharing of molecules between the ring motifs . According to platon, the water-bearing cavities comprise 11.6% of the unit cell volume.

elements.clean_text:
Structural description of {[Cd4(dms)4(H2O)4]⋅H2O} n  (4)

The asymmetric unit of compound 4 contains a divalent cadmium atom, a dms ligand, an aqua ligand, and a water molecule of crystallization best modeled at quarter-occupancy. In contrast to 1-3, there are no dipyridylamide ligands present in 4. The cadmium atoms adopt a distorted {CdO8} square antiprismatic coordination environment, comprised of chelating carboxylate groups from two dms ligands, single oxygen atom donors from an additional three dms ligands, and the bound water molecule ( a). Bond lengths and angles within the coordination environment are listed in  .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0145" view="all">The dms ligands in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> adopt a complicated exotetradentate μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-κ<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-O,O′:O′,O″:O″,O″′:O″ binding mode, in which one oxygen atom from each carboxylate group binds only to one cadmium, a third oxygen atom bridges two cadmium atoms, and the fourth oxygen atom bridges three cadmium atoms. Four triply bridging dms oxygen atoms and four cadmium atoms construct a distorted cuboid {Cd<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} cluster building unit (b). These are wrapped by the four full dms ligands that provide the triply bridging dms oxygen atom donors, to construct a larger {Cd<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(dms)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} cluster motif (c). Within the clusters, the Cd⋯Cd distances measure 3.931<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å across two opposite cuboid faces, and 3.791<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å across the other four contiguous cuboid faces. Four of the cuboid edges are bridged by the other oxygen atoms of the dms carboxylate groups that bear the triply bridging oxygen donor atoms. Four other cuboid edges are bridged by dms ligands in a 1,4-chelating fashion. Adjacent {Cd<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(dms)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} units are connected to four others in a pseudo-tetrahedral arrangement by the full span of the dms ligands (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>), to construct a 3-D [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(dms)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> coordination polymer network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0060"></ce:float-anchor>a). If individual {Cd<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(dms)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>} units are considered to be 4-connected tetrahedral nodes, the coordination polymer net simplifies to a commonly encountered 6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> diamondoid network (b). Isolated water molecules of crystallization occupy narrow incipient channels throughout the 3-D net comprising 8.4% of the unit cell volume, held to the coordination polymer backbone by weak hydrogen bonding to the bound water molecules ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The dms ligands in 4 adopt a complicated exotetradentate μ4-κ4-O,O':O',O":O",O"':O" binding mode, in which one oxygen atom from each carboxylate group binds only to one cadmium, a third oxygen atom bridges two cadmium atoms, and the fourth oxygen atom bridges three cadmium atoms. Four triply bridging dms oxygen atoms and four cadmium atoms construct a distorted cuboid {Cd4O4} cluster building unit (b). These are wrapped by the four full dms ligands that provide the triply bridging dms oxygen atom donors, to construct a larger {Cd4(dms)4(H2O)4} cluster motif (c). Within the clusters, the Cd⋯Cd distances measure 3.931Å across two opposite cuboid faces, and 3.791Å across the other four contiguous cuboid faces. Four of the cuboid edges are bridged by the other oxygen atoms of the dms carboxylate groups that bear the triply bridging oxygen donor atoms. Four other cuboid edges are bridged by dms ligands in a 1,4-chelating fashion. Adjacent {Cd4(dms)4(H2O)4} units are connected to four others in a pseudo-tetrahedral arrangement by the full span of the dms ligands ( ), to construct a 3-D [Cd4(dms)4(H2O)4] n  coordination polymer network ( a). If individual {Cd4(dms)4(H2O)4} units are considered to be 4-connected tetrahedral nodes, the coordination polymer net simplifies to a commonly encountered 66 diamondoid network (b). Isolated water molecules of crystallization occupy narrow incipient channels throughout the 3-D net comprising 8.4% of the unit cell volume, held to the coordination polymer backbone by weak hydrogen bonding to the bound water molecules ().

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st100">Luminescence spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0150" view="all">Solid samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were irradiated with ultraviolet light to examine their potential for photoluminescent behavior. Due to the lack of aromatic ligands in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, no emissive behavior was observed. The excitation spectra for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were recorded by monitoring emission at 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, revealing maximum excitation wavelengths of 245<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, and 253<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively. Upon excitation at these wavelengths, blue-violet visible light emission was observed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The emission maxima for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were 394<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, 394<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, and 407<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0065"></ce:float-anchor>). When the pure 3-pmna ligand was irradiated at 235<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, a weak emission with broad spectral profile centered at 305<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm was observed. For 4-pmina these values were 328<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 527<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively. The fluorescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are thus ascribed to π–π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> molecular orbital transitions within the aromatic ring systems of the dipyridylamide ligands, with a blue-shift caused by donation of the pyridyl nitrogen atoms to cadmium .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence spectra

Solid samples of 1-4 were irradiated with ultraviolet light to examine their potential for photoluminescent behavior. Due to the lack of aromatic ligands in 4, no emissive behavior was observed. The excitation spectra for 1-3 were recorded by monitoring emission at 400nm, revealing maximum excitation wavelengths of 245nm, 250nm, and 253nm, respectively. Upon excitation at these wavelengths, blue-violet visible light emission was observed in 1-3. The emission maxima for 1-3 were 394nm, 394nm, and 407nm, respectively ( ). When the pure 3-pmna ligand was irradiated at 235nm, a weak emission with broad spectral profile centered at 305nm was observed. For 4-pmina these values were 328nm and 527nm, respectively. The fluorescent properties of 1-3 are thus ascribed to π-π∗ molecular orbital transitions within the aromatic ring systems of the dipyridylamide ligands, with a blue-shift caused by donation of the pyridyl nitrogen atoms to cadmium .

elements.clean_text:
Nitrobenzene sensing

Compound 3 shows capability for detection of nitrobenzene ( ) in ethanol suspension. Addition of small aliquots of nitrobenzene dissolved in DMSO (1×10-4 M) resulted in decrease of the coordination polymer luminescence intensity upon excitation with ultraviolet light (λ ex =335nm). This loss of emission signal is attributed to charge transfer from the excited states of the ligand molecular orbitals within the coordination polymer, to those of the adsorbed electron-withdrawing nitrobenzene analyte . The intensity factor (I o - I)/I o (I o =maximum intensity in the absence of analyte) reaches a level about 32% of the initial I o value after 100μL of the stock analyte solution was added (). As a control experiment, aliquots of a benzene solution in DMSO (1×10-4 M) were added to an ethanol suspensions of 3. No decrease in luminescence intensity was observed. Thus, it is averred that the nitro group of the analyte is key for luminescence diminishing within coordination polymer 3.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st110">Thermal properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0160" view="all">According to thermogravimetric analysis, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> underwent dehydration between 100 and 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with a mass loss of 7.5% corresponding to ejection of all bound and unbound water molecules (6.9% calc’d). The mass remained stable until 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> underwent loss of unbound water between 20 and 70<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with a mass loss of 14.0% matching well with the predicted value of 14.3%. The bound water molecules were lost above 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and ligand ejection occurred above 270<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> lost its unbound water molecules between 40 and 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with a mass loss of 7.0%, matching extremely well with the predicted value of 7.1%. Ligand removal occurred above 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> was dehydrated between 140 and 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with a mass loss of 8.0% matching very closely with the predicted value of 8.1%. The mass of this 3-D phase remained stable until 375<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. TGA traces for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are shown in , respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal properties

According to thermogravimetric analysis, compound 1 underwent dehydration between 100 and 150°C, with a mass loss of 7.5% corresponding to ejection of all bound and unbound water molecules (6.9% calc'd). The mass remained stable until 250°C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. Compound 2 underwent loss of unbound water between 20 and 70°C, with a mass loss of 14.0% matching well with the predicted value of 14.3%. The bound water molecules were lost above 100°C, and ligand ejection occurred above 270°C. Compound 3 lost its unbound water molecules between 40 and 250°C, with a mass loss of 7.0%, matching extremely well with the predicted value of 7.1%. Ligand removal occurred above 250°C. Compound 4 was dehydrated between 140 and 180°C, with a mass loss of 8.0% matching very closely with the predicted value of 8.1%. The mass of this 3-D phase remained stable until 375°C. TGA traces for 1-4 are shown in , respectively.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st115">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0165" view="all">The length of an aliphatic dicarboxylate ligand with two methyl group substituents played a large role in topology and dimensionality in a pair of cadmium coordination polymers containing the seldom used 3-pyridylmethylnicotinamide ligand. Altering the nitrogen donor disposition within the dipyridylamide ligand resulted in a shift from a 1-D ribbon topology to a new binodal 3D network, facilitated by amide oxygen atom binding to cadmium. A higher temperature synthetic regime resulted in a dipyridylamide-free tetranuclear cuboid cluster based cadmium dimethylsuccinate 3-D coordination polymer. While all materials containing a dipyridylamide ligand in this study manifested luminescent behavior upon ultraviolet irradiation in the solid state, the cadmium dimethylsuccinate coordination polymer <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with the longer spanning 4-pyridylmethylisonicotinamide ligand also displayed luminescent quenching in the presence of nitrobenzene. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> therefore may have potential as an explosives trace residue sensor.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The length of an aliphatic dicarboxylate ligand with two methyl group substituents played a large role in topology and dimensionality in a pair of cadmium coordination polymers containing the seldom used 3-pyridylmethylnicotinamide ligand. Altering the nitrogen donor disposition within the dipyridylamide ligand resulted in a shift from a 1-D ribbon topology to a new binodal 3D network, facilitated by amide oxygen atom binding to cadmium. A higher temperature synthetic regime resulted in a dipyridylamide-free tetranuclear cuboid cluster based cadmium dimethylsuccinate 3-D coordination polymer. While all materials containing a dipyridylamide ligand in this study manifested luminescent behavior upon ultraviolet irradiation in the solid state, the cadmium dimethylsuccinate coordination polymer 3 with the longer spanning 4-pyridylmethylisonicotinamide ligand also displayed luminescent quenching in the presence of nitrobenzene. Compound 3 therefore may have potential as an explosives trace residue sensor.

Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (115mg, 0.372mmol), 3-pmna (76mg, 0.36mmol), 2,2-dimethylglutaric acid (58mg, 0.37mmol), and 1mL of a 1.0M NaOH solution were mixed with 10mL of distilled H2O in a 23mL Teflon-lined acid digestion bomb. The bomb was sealed and heated in an oven at 120°C for 24h, and then was cooled slowly to 25°C. IR (cm-1): 3313 (w), 2987 (w), 1647 (s), 1598 (w), 1560 (s), 1475 (m), 1411(m), 1375 (w), 1361 (w), 1306 (m), 1257 (m), 1197 (w), 1164 (w), 1131 (w), 1054 (w), 1030 (w), 993 (w), 956 (w), 902 (w), 784 (m), 747 (m), 700 (s), 672 (s).

Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (112mg, 0.363mmol), 4-pmina (79mg, 0.37mmol), 2,2-dimethylsuccinic acid (55mg, 0.38mmol), and 1mL of a 1.0M NaOH solution were mixed with 10mL of distilled H2O in a 23mL Teflon-lined acid digestion bomb. The bomb was sealed and heated in an oven at 100°C for 96h, and then was cooled slowly to 25°C. The mass remained stable until 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescence spectra

Solid samples of 1-4 were irradiated with ultraviolet light to examine their potential for photoluminescent behavior. Due to the lack of aromatic ligands in 4, no emissive behavior was observed. The excitation spectra for 1-3 were recorded by monitoring emission at 400nm, revealing maximum excitation wavelengths of 245nm, 250nm, and 253nm, respectively. Upon excitation at these wavelengths, blue-violet visible light emission was observed in 1-3. The emission maxima for 1-3 were 394nm, 394nm, and 407nm, respectively ( ). When the pure 3-pmna ligand was irradiated at 235nm, a weak emission with broad spectral profile centered at 305nm was observed. For 4-pmina these values were 328nm and 527nm, respectively. The fluorescent properties of 1-3 are thus ascribed to π-π∗ molecular orbital transitions within the aromatic ring systems of the dipyridylamide ligands, with a blue-shift caused by donation of the pyridyl nitrogen atoms to cadmium .

Thermal properties

According to thermogravimetric analysis, compound 1 underwent dehydration between 100 and 150°C, with a mass loss of 7.5% corresponding to ejection of all bound and unbound water molecules (6.9% calc'd). The mass remained stable until 250°C, whereupon ligand ejection occurred. Compound 2 underwent loss of unbound water between 20 and 70°C, with a mass loss of 14.0% matching well with the predicted value of 14.3%. The bound water molecules were lost above 100°C, and ligand ejection occurred above 270°C. Compound 3 lost its unbound water molecules between 40 and 250°C, with a mass loss of 7.0%, matching extremely well with the predicted value of 7.1%. Ligand removal occurred above 250°C. Compound 4 was dehydrated between 140 and 180°C, with a mass loss of 8.0% matching very closely with the predicted value of 8.1%. The mass of this 3-D phase remained stable until 375°C. TGA traces for 1-4 are shown in , respectively.
